Sentence: Homer and Tod are not Faye's only admirers; Tod accompanies Faye out to a campsite in the hills where her (Faye) sometime-boyfriend Earle and his (Tod) companion Miguel live
The evening ends when Earle clubs the flirtatious Miguel on the head and Tod futilely chases after Faye in the woods, intending to rape her (Faye)
Faye takes advantage of Homer's meekness and generosity, easily compelling him (Homer) to allow Earle and Miguel to move into his (Earle) garage
Homer and Faye seek Tod out after several weeks, convincing him (Homer) to attend a cockfight Miguel and Earle are holding in Homer's garage
After the violent cockfight, Claude, Abe, Earle, and Miguel sit in Homer's living room, drinking and lusting after Faye, who is barely dressed in unbuttoned silk pajamas
In the early morning, Homer and Earle discover Miguel in bed with Faye, which leads Earle and Miguel to fight
